entry.title: Compressed Statistics Notes I
entry.content:
I ran some numerical simulations and obtained some complicated results. Just want to get this out there.

So a recap of the question: given a 5-ary channel, our building blocks for reasonable channels are the threshold channels ViV_iVi​, where we send a one if we see ≥i\geq i≥i ones. In the 3-ary channel case, there was no question about how to mix V2V_2V2​ and V3V_3V3​ to obtain channels that distinguish arbitrary hypotheses split over p∗p^*p∗ in (12,1)(\frac 1 2, 1)(21​,1). However, in the 5-ary case, we need to decide how to select an affine mixture (α1,α2,α3)(\alpha_1, \alpha_2, \alpha_3)(α1​,α2​,α3​), where ∑iαi=1\sum_i \alpha_i = 1∑i​αi​=1, so that α1V3+α2V4+α3V5\alpha_1 V_3 + \alpha_2 V_4 + \alpha_3 V_5α1​V3​+α2​V4​+α3​V5​ maximizes the separation of the hypotheses (which we currently measure as maximizing the convergence rate to a single fixed point).

How do we choose this channel? Well, our heuristic currently is that the one with the maximal derivative at the fixed point maximizes the convergence rate (when I ran numerical tests to find the empirical convergence rate to an epsilon neighborhood of the iterated function, I got results that supported this heuristic). So we should maximized the derivative at the fixed point.

By the fixed point constraint α1V3(p∗)+α2V4(p∗)+α3V5(p∗)=p∗\alpha_1 V_3(p^*) + \alpha_2 V_4(p^*) + \alpha_3 V_5(p^*)=p^*α1​V3​(p∗)+α2​V4​(p∗)+α3​V5​(p∗)=p∗, we reduce one of the parameters. We then maximize the derivative ddpα1V3(p)+α2V4(p)+α3V5(p)∣p=p∗\frac d{dp} \alpha_1 V_3(p) + \alpha_2 V_4(p) + \alpha_3 V_5(p) |_{p=p^*}dpd​α1​V3​(p)+α2​V4​(p)+α3​V5​(p)∣p=p∗​, which in this case is a 1-dimensional maximization. The result I get is not a simple one. It turns out that there is a transition point, where if the fixed point p∗p^*p∗ is on one side, it is optimal to use α1V3+α2V4\alpha_1 V_3 + \alpha_2 V_4α1​V3​+α2​V4​ (no V5V_5V5​, with α1,α2\alpha_1,\alpha_2α1​,α2​ of course depending on the fixed point) and on the other side it’s optimal to use α2V4+α3V5\alpha_2 V_4 + \alpha_3 V_5α2​V4​+α3​V5​. The transition occurs somewhere between 67\frac 6 776​ and 78\frac 7 887​.

My thoughts:

  1. I could pin down that transition point exactly, but I’m not sure that it’s that important
  2. This method is going to get harder on 7-ary and larger channels; the optimization might still be analyzable; it is a ⌊m−32⌋\lfloor \frac{m-3}2 \rfloor⌊2m−3​⌋-dimensional optimization of the form

max⁡α⃗∑i=⌊n+12⌋nαiVi’(p∗)s.t∑iαi=1∑iαiVi(p∗)=p∗. \begin{aligned} \max_{\vec \alpha} & \sum_{i=\lfloor \frac {n+1} 2 \rfloor}^n \alpha_i V_i’(p^*) \\ \text{s.t} & \sum_i \alpha_i = 1 \\ & \sum_i \alpha_i V_i(p^*) = p^*. \end{aligned} αmax​s.t​i=⌊2n+1​⌋∑n​αi​Vi​’(p∗)i∑​αi​=1i∑​αi​Vi​(p∗)=p∗.​

  1. The 5-ary case suggests that the result will be a somewhat complicated piecewise-linear function.

entry.title: Testing Jekyll, Markdown, KaTeX, and References

link.title: Testing Jekyll, Markdown, KaTeX, and References

entry.content:
To link throughout the site about me use brackets and parenthesis. Same with linking to outside pages. For example, I’m a fan of the Wallis product.

KaTeX’s display mode requires using the {\% katex display \%} tag. c=±a2+b2(1) c = \pm\sqrt{a^2 + b^2} \tag{1} c=±a2+b2​(1) Same with other environments, such as the aligned mode. 5+5=1010=5+5 \begin{aligned} 5+5 & = 10 \\ 10 & = 5+5 \end{aligned} 5+510​=10=5+5​

The katexmm tag allows you to wrap many inline instances of LaTeX and render them as normal. Consider a function f:X→Yf: \mathcal X \to \mathcal Yf:X→Y, where X,Y\mathcal X, \mathcal YX,Y are measure spaces equipped with the measures μX,μY\mu_{\mathcal X}, \mu_{\mathcal Y}μX​,μY​.

We can also do display-type environments and use \tag to number equations lim⁡n→∞∫0π2sin⁡(x)ndx=lim⁡n→∞(2n)!!(2n+1)!!=π2.(2)\lim_{n \to \infty} \int_0^{\frac \pi 2} \sin(x)^n dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{ (2n)!!}{(2n+1)!!} = \frac \pi 2. \tag{2}n→∞lim​∫02π​​sin(x)ndx=n→∞lim​(2n+1)!!(2n)!!​=2π​.(2) Unfortunately, the numbering is all manual, e.g. equation (2). Furthermore, the katexmm tag does not recognize the officially supported \[,\] LaTeX delimiters. But hey, no one’s died yet, right?

Here is how we make a footnote1. We can also automatically generate references using jekyll-scholar and a BibTeX file (Shamir, 2014).

References

  1. Shamir, O. (2014). Fundamental Limits of Online and Distributed Algorithms for Statistical Learning and Estimation. NIPS Conference.

Footnotes

  1. We can even make footnotes in footnotes2. ↩

  2. DFW eat your heart out3. ↩

  3. This is a boomerism, the meaning of which has been lost to time but we keep using it to propagate the idealized memories of our parents. ↩

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
